title: How to Recolor Anything on Gimp

steps.title: Open GIMP on your computer.
steps.content: Open GIMP on your computer. The GIMP icon looks like a cartoon animal with a paintbrush in its mouth. You can find it on your Start menu on Windows or in the Applications folder on Mac.

steps.title: Select the File tab on the top-left.
steps.content: Select the File tab on the top-left. This button is either on the tab bar at the top of the app window (PC) or on the menu bar at the top of your screen (Mac). It will open your file options. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Click Open on the File menu.
steps.content: Click Open on the File menu. This will open a new pop-up window, and allow you to select the image you want to open. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Select the image you want to recolor.
steps.content: Select the image you want to recolor. Find and click on the file name in the pop-up window. You will see a preview of the image on the right-hand side of the pop-up when it's selected.

steps.title: Click the Open button.
steps.content: Click the Open button. This will open the selected image in GIMP. [3] X Research source If you're prompted to convert the image profile to a compatible color scale for GIMP, click Convert for the best results.

steps.title: Click the Layer tab at the top.
steps.content: Click the Layer tab at the top. You can find this button on the tab bar at the top of the app window (PC) or on the menu bar at the top of your screen (Mac).

steps.title: Click New Layer on the Layer menu.
steps.content: Click New Layer on the Layer menu. This will allow you to create a new layer on your image. You can use this layer to make color manipulations on your image. This option will open a new pop-up titled "Create a New Layer."

steps.title: Select Transparency next to "Fill with.
steps.content: Select Transparency next to "Fill with. " In the "Create a New Layer" pop-up, make sure the "Transparency" option is selected as the layer fill at the bottom. In some versions of GIMP, you may see "Layer Fill Type" instead of "Fill with." If you have a "Layer Type" option, you can set it to "Normal."

steps.title: Click OK in the "Create a New Layer" pop-up.
steps.content: Click OK in the "Create a New Layer" pop-up. This will create a new, transparent layer on your image.

steps.title: Click the Free Select (Lasso) tool in the toolkit.
steps.content: Click the Free Select (Lasso) tool in the toolkit. This button looks like a lasso icon in the toolkit section on the top-left. It will allow you to select an area in the picture.

steps.title: Check the Feather edges option on the bottom-left.
steps.content: Check the Feather edges option on the bottom-left. When you select the Free Select tool, you can enable this feature on the bottom-left of the app window. This will give softer edges to your selection. You can increase the Radius value under the "Feather edges" option for even softer edges.

steps.title: Select the outline of the area you want to recolor.
steps.content: Select the outline of the area you want to recolor. Use the Free Select (Lasso) tool with your mouse, and draw an outline around the area to recolor. Make sure the new, transparent layer is selected on the right-hand side, and not the original picture. When you finish the outline, you'll see dashed lines around your selection.

steps.title: Click the "Bucket Fill" tool in the toolkit.
steps.content: Click the "Bucket Fill" tool in the toolkit. This button looks like a paint bucket in the toolkit section in the upper-left corner. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Click the front color below the toolkit.
steps.content: Click the front color below the toolkit. This will open the color selector in a new pop-up.

steps.title: Select the color you want to use.
steps.content: Select the color you want to use. You can select any color in the color selector pop-up.

steps.title: Click the outlined area on the picture.
steps.content: Click the outlined area on the picture. This will fill the selected area with a solid color. Again, make sure the new, transparent layer is selected on the right-hand side; not the original image.

steps.title: Click the Mode drop-down at the top of the Layers list.
steps.content: Click the Mode drop-down at the top of the Layers list. You can find a list of all your image layers on the right-hand side of the app window. By default, the layer mode should be set to "Normal."

steps.title: Select Color in the Mode drop-down.
steps.content: Select Color in the Mode drop-down. This will change your transparent layer's mode to a "Color" layer, and change the color of the selected area in your original picture.

steps.title: Select the Eraser tool in the toolkit.
steps.content: Select the Eraser tool in the toolkit. This button looks like a rectangle eraser icon in the toolkit section on the top-left.

steps.title: Erase the extra color around the recolored area.
steps.content: Erase the extra color around the recolored area. You can use the Eraser tool to manually trim the edges, and remove the extra recolor around your selection.

steps.title: Create a new, transparent layer.
steps.content: Create a new, transparent layer. Follow the steps in the Part 2 above to create a new, transparent layer on top of your image with no fill. Make sure that this is a separate layer than the "Color Mode" layer you may use with the Bucket Fill tool above.

steps.title: Select the "Paintbrush" tool in the toolkit.
steps.content: Select the "Paintbrush" tool in the toolkit. This button looks like a paintbrush icon in the toolkit on the top-left of the app window. [5] X Research source This tool will allow you to manually paint new colors on the pictures. Optionally, you can adjust your paintbrush stroke's size, angle, hardness and other attributes on the bottom-left section.

steps.title: Click the front color layer below the toolkit.
steps.content: Click the front color layer below the toolkit. On the left-hand side, click the front layer of the two color layers, and open the color selector.

steps.title: Select the color you want to use on your paintbrush.
steps.content: Select the color you want to use on your paintbrush. You can select any color in the color selector pop-up or enter RGB/HTML values to pick an exact color.

steps.title: Click the Mode drop-down at the top of the Layers.
steps.content: Click the Mode drop-down at the top of the Layers. This drop-down menu is located at the top of all your image layers on the right-hand side, and should be set to "Normal" by default. Make sure the new, transparent layer you created for the paintbrush process is selected on the Layers list. Do not select the original picture here.

steps.title: Select Hue in the Mode drop-down.
steps.content: Select Hue in the Mode drop-down. This will allow you to change the color hue of the areas you paint with your paintbrush.

steps.title: Paint on the picture to recolor anything.
steps.content: Paint on the picture to recolor anything. You can use your mouse to paint on the picture, and change the color hue of any part of the image. You should be painting on the transparent "Hue" layer, and not the original picture.

steps.title: Right-click the original picture on the Layers list.
steps.content: Right-click the original picture on the Layers list. The Layers section is located on the right-hand side of the app window. This will open your right-click options.

steps.title: Select Flatten Image on the right-click menu.
steps.content: Select Flatten Image on the right-click menu. You can find this option at the bottom or top of the right-click menu. This will merge all your layers, and create one, single image layer with all your recoloring work saved.

steps.title: Click the File menu on the top-left.
steps.content: Click the File menu on the top-left. You can find this option at the top of the app window (PC) or on the menu bar near the upper-left corner of your screen (Mac). [6] X Research source

steps.title: Select Export As on the File menu.
steps.content: Select Export As on the File menu. This will open a new dialogue box, and allow you to save your new image to your computer as a separate file. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Select a saving location for your new picture.
steps.content: Select a saving location for your new picture. Find and click the folder you want to save your new picture in the dialogue box.

steps.title: Click Select File Type at the bottom.
steps.content: Click Select File Type at the bottom. You can find this option at the bottom of the dialogue box. It will extend a list of all the image file types you can export your new picture as.

steps.title: Select an image format for your new image.
steps.content: Select an image format for your new image. You can select a common image format like JPEG, TIFF, or PNG here.

steps.title: Click the Export button.
steps.content: Click the Export button. This button is on the bottom-right corner of the dialogue box. It will export and save your new image to the selected folder. [8] X Research source Some image formats like JPEG may prompt you to select an image quality in an extra pop-up. If you're prompted, you can optionally adjust the properties here, and click Export to finalize.
